Package com.atakmap.comms

Class CommsProvider

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.atakmap.comms.CommsProvider
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    DefaultCommsProvider
    public abstract class CommsProvider
extends java.lang.Object
    CommsProvider is the abstract base class for all implementations of communication methods. Classes extending this interface should indicate which features are supported. CommsFeatures include:
    • NONE:

      Does not have to be explicitly supported, all methods linked to this FEATURE are required to support the bare minimum functionality of TAK.

    • MISSION_PACK_SETTINGS:

      Settings for mission packages, and how they get transferred.

    • ENDPOINT_SUPPORT:

      Settings for connecting to a takserver, and functionality that requires a takserver or other endpoint connections. e.g. Mesh endpoint

    • FILE_IO: *

      FileIO Provider management and settings.

    • INTERFACE_OPTIONS: *

      Manage the network interfaces, and socket settings.

    • CRYPTO:

      Crypto accessible by the TAK application. A CommsProvider may implement custom crypto protections that may or may not be exposed to the rest of the application.

    • VPN: *

      Required for supporting Tactical VPN by Kranze Technologies

    • UNKNOWN_CONTACT:

      Used by CommsMapComponent to determine if we are allowed to send to unknown contacts. CommsProviders implementing this feature must support sending messages to UIDs that do not have an associated Contact card. An example of this is sending a GeoChat to "All Chat Rooms". There are no associated methods, but it does change the list of UIDs being sent to the CommsProvider when calling, for example, sendCoT(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String>, java.lang.String, com.atakmap.commoncommo.CoTSendMethod). The primary purpose of this feature is to support information-centric networking environments.

      This feature is not supported by the DefaultCommsProvider as a part of ATAK.

    If a CommsFeature is not specified as supported, linked methods should not be called. A call to an unimplemented method will result in a logged Warning, and null/error returns where applicable. To avoid calling unimplemented functions, for a CommsFeature to be declared as supported, all relevant methods should be implemented.
